senses.definition: for or relating to young people
dictionary_examples: a junior tennis tournament
senses.learner_example: I am used to work[ing] with children, as an instructor for a junior football team in my city.

senses.definition: lower or less advanced in rank, position, or time in service
dictionary_examples: the junior senator from Illinois
Alfredo is a junior partner in the law firm.
senses.learner_example: At the moment [I']m a junior member of the Kato Club in Amsterdam and [I']m training there because it is so close to the University and my apartment.

senses.definition: a student in the third year of a program of study at a high school, college, or university
dictionary_examples: a high school junior
She's a junior at the University of Pennsylvania.
senses.learner_example: One day my geography teacher gathered the seniors and the juniors in our class, plus the principal and other two or three teachers, so that they could listen to me making a speech on my beautiful home-country.

senses.definition: 10/20, etc. months/years younger than someone
dictionary_examples: He was born in April, so he’s three months my junior.
senses.learner_example: I have a sister four years my junior and in my opinion we have no reason to complain.

senses.definition: the first half of the day, from the time when the sun rises or you wake up until the middle of the day
dictionary_examples: Friday morning
I got up late this morning.
I work three mornings a week at the bookstore.
I have a dentist appointment tomorrow morning.
senses.learner_example: I'll see you on Saturday morning.

senses.definition: used to say hello to someone in the morning
dictionary_examples: Good morning, Sarah!

senses.definition: during the early part of the day
dictionary_examples: I listen to the radio in the morning.
senses.learner_example: He love[s] to get up early in the morning.

senses.definition: tomorrow morning
dictionary_examples: I'll pack in the morning.

senses.definition: 2/3/4, etc. o'clock at night
dictionary_examples: My car alarm went off at 3 o'clock in the morning.
senses.learner_example: I came home at 4 o'clock in the morning.

senses.definition: farther than usual or as far as possible
dictionary_examples: She ran toward me, her arms open wide.
senses.learner_example: She came into the living room and saw me standing on the stairs with my eyes opened wide.

senses.definition: having a larger distance from one side to the other than is usual or expected
dictionary_examples: a wide river/road
senses.learner_example: I'm going to stay here two weeks in a big hotel near a wide river.

senses.definition: a lot of different types of thing
dictionary_examples: The library has a wide range of information.
They sell a wide selection of chocolates.
senses.learner_example: There is a very wide choice of activities!

senses.definition: having a distance of 5 miles/10 feet, etc. from one side to the other
dictionary_examples: The swimming pool is 20 feet wide.
senses.learner_example: From the two meters wide window I can overlook the city and the lake.

senses.definition: to be completely awake
dictionary_examples: "Is Oliver awake yet?" "Yes, he's wide awake and running around his bedroom."
senses.learner_example: Sometimes, when I have put my children to bed, half an hour later an aircraft flies over and my two-year-old daughter is wide awake again.

senses.definition: a long way into something from the top or outside
dictionary_examples: They traveled deep into the forest.
He thrust his hands deep in(to) his pockets.
senses.learner_example: I just fall deep into the story, into the writer's own world.

senses.definition: having a long distance from the top to the bottom
dictionary_examples: a deep river/sea/lake
The water's not deep here - look, I can touch the bottom.
The water's only ankle-/knee-/waist-deep, so we'll be able to get across the river easily.
senses.learner_example: That place is good for the famili[e]s too, because [the] water [is] not so deep.

senses.definition: A deep color is strong and dark.
dictionary_examples: deep purple
senses.learner_example: He is tall and has got black hair and beautiful deep brown eyes.

senses.definition: A deep sound is low.
dictionary_examples: a wonderfully deep voice
senses.learner_example: "I'm not Gary," a strange and deep voice answered, "I'm someone who wants to warn you that tomorrow, you are going to die."

senses.definition: A deep feeling or experience is very strong.
dictionary_examples: deep regret
Their son has been a deep disappointment to them.
senses.learner_example: I fell into a deep depression, and took an extremely long time to recover.

senses.definition: serious and difficult to understand
dictionary_examples: a deep and meaningful conversation
senses.learner_example: I think we really need to go back to the classics to re[ce]ive something from the deep thinkers.

senses.definition: to fill your lungs with air
dictionary_examples: Take a deep breath and relax.
senses.learner_example: But if you took a deep breath after reading the question, don't worry.

senses.definition: having a distance of 6 inches/4 feet, etc. from the top to the bottom, or from the front to the back
dictionary_examples: This end of the pool is eight feet deep.
senses.learner_example: Her father's friend, who is a professional scuba-diver, invited her to do her first immers[i]on on the reefs, 15 meter[s] deep.

senses.definition: when someone is sleeping in a way that makes it difficult to wake them up
dictionary_examples: He fell into a deep sleep.
senses.learner_example: And then, he fell to a deep sleep, putting his sack next to him.

senses.term: throw sb in at the deep end
senses.definition: to make someone start a new and difficult job or activity without helping them or preparing them for it
dictionary_examples: My first job was to organize a huge conference - they really threw me in at the deep end!
senses.learner_example: Sometimes we can be thrown in at the deep end and have qualms about making a decision.

senses.definition: giving all of your attention to what you are thinking or talking about, and not noticing anything else
dictionary_examples: I noticed that Ali and Ben were deep in conversation.
senses.learner_example: He was deep in thought, chewing on something brown and rectangular.

senses.definition: If a feeling or a problem goes deep, it is very strong or serious and has existed for a long time.
dictionary_examples: Their commitment to this town runs deep.

senses.definition: If you know or feel something deep down, you are certain that it is true, or you feel it strongly although you do not admit it or show it.
dictionary_examples: Deep down, I knew that I was right.
senses.learner_example: No, because I [feel] deep down that it's wrong to put animals behind bars.

senses.definition: used before a noun to refer to a single thing or person but not a particular thing or person or not one that you have referred to before
dictionary_examples: She's got a boyfriend.
Someone left an umbrella here yesterday.
Is he a friend of yours?
senses.learner_example: You can make a quick snack, for example a sandwich.

senses.definition: one
dictionary_examples: a hundred dollars
a dozen eggs
senses.learner_example: Dear Ally, All my friends [from] school were here, more than a hundred people.

senses.definition: used to mean any or every thing or person of the type you are referring to
dictionary_examples: Can you ride a bike?
A child needs love.
A cheetah can run faster than a lion.
senses.learner_example: I don't need it because I'm too old to have a doll.

senses.definition: used to state what type of thing or person something or someone is
dictionary_examples: Sally's an engineer.
It's a rabbit.
senses.learner_example: She's a teacher.

senses.definition: used before some phrases saying how much of something there is
dictionary_examples: a few days
a little bit of yarn
senses.learner_example: Usually people in Poland are very busy so we do not have a lot of time for cooking.

senses.definition: used before some action nouns when referring to one example of the action
dictionary_examples: Take a look at this, Jez.
I'm just going to take a ride.
senses.learner_example: I took a shower and ate my breakfast.

senses.definition: used before the first but not the second of two nouns that are often used together
dictionary_examples: a cup and saucer
a knife and fork
senses.learner_example: I like a clean fork and knife.

senses.definition: used when referring to a unit of something, especially something you eat or drink
dictionary_examples: I'd love a coffee.
All I had for lunch was a yogurt.
senses.learner_example: We both had a coke and a hot dog.

senses.definition: used between a fraction and a unit of measurement
dictionary_examples: half a mile
a quarter of a kilo
three-quarters of an hour
senses.learner_example: The lesson is half an hour but you have to be ther[e] 10 minutes before.

senses.definition: used when referring to a certain period of time
dictionary_examples: Take one tablet three times a day.
She earns $100,000 a year.
senses.learner_example: I can write to him or her twice a week.

senses.definition: someone who controls a trial in court, decides how criminals should be punished, and makes decisions about legal matters
dictionary_examples: The judge ruled that they had acted correctly.
senses.learner_example: To the surprise of everyone in the village, the judge found her guilty but didn't send her to jail because he thought she should take care of Linda, who had no other relatives.

senses.definition: someone who decides which person or thing wins a competition
dictionary_examples: the Olympic judges
senses.learner_example: However, the Astro singing competition is different. The winner will be [decided] according [to] the marks given by the judge.

senses.term: a bad/good, etc. judge of sth
senses.definition: someone who is usually wrong/usually right, etc. when they judge something
dictionary_examples: a good judge of character
senses.learner_example: She is a very good judge of character and the institute has reared some very promising scientists.

senses.definition: used to express the reasons why you have a particular opinion
dictionary_examples: Judging by what he said, I think it's very unlikely that he'll be able to support your application.
senses.learner_example: I didn't like San Diego so much - just judging by my first impression.

senses.term: not judge a book by its cover
senses.definition: to not decide what someone or something is like only by looking at them
dictionary_examples: You know, his desk is a mess but don't judge a book by it's cover, he does careful, detailed work.
senses.learner_example: I'm simply pointing out one should never judge a book by it's cover as things aren't alway[s] what they seem.

senses.definition: to have or develop an opinion about something or someone, especially after thinking carefully
dictionary_examples: So far, he seems to be handling the job well, but it's really too soon to judge.
It's difficult to judge whether the new system really is an improvement.
The meeting was judged to have been a success.
I'm hopeless at judging distance(s).
senses.learner_example: It's very difficult to judge, because so many young people leave Poland and go to [an]other country.

senses.definition: to officially decide who will be the winner of a competition
dictionary_examples: I've been asked to judge the art competition.
senses.learner_example: If you don't object, we would like to see you judging the competition and giving pr[ize]s to the winners.

senses.definition: to have a bad opinion of someone's behavior, often because you think you are better than them
dictionary_examples: What gives you the right to judge people?
senses.learner_example: "I'm not judging you, dear," I whispered softly.

senses.definition: a small area that is different from the area around it
dictionary_examples: a bald patch
There are icy patches on the road.
senses.learner_example: All my senses were sharpened, I could clearly see the tired smile of the bass-guitarist and wet patches on his T-shirt.

senses.definition: a small area of land used for a particular purpose
dictionary_examples: a cabbage/vegetable patch
senses.learner_example: My father had a big allotment with different vegetables like turnips, beet, etc., etc. [At] my house there was also a vegetable patch.

senses.definition: a piece of material that you use to cover a hole in your clothes or in other material
dictionary_examples: He had leather patches sewn on the elbows of his jacket.
senses.learner_example: And my mother cherishes her family [heirloom] handed down for generations - it's a quilt with s[e]wn patches on it, representing what each of the women's strongest passion was. My mother s[e]wed on her patch presenting her childhood fascination of The Beatles.

senses.definition: to try to improve your relationship with someone after you have had an argument
dictionary_examples: Has he managed to patch things up with her?
senses.learner_example: Then in bed I asked my goddess to make my parents patch up their quarrel.

senses.definition: a difficult time
dictionary_examples: I think their marriage is going through a bad patch.
senses.learner_example: We all went through a rough patch when my mother turned out to have cancer.

senses.definition: to repair a hole in a piece of clothing or other material by sewing a piece of material over it
dictionary_examples: to patch your sweater
senses.learner_example: There were also clothes to be men[d]ed and patched, socks to be darned.

senses.definition: considering all the facts in a fair way
dictionary_examples: The news program prides itself on its balanced reporting.
senses.learner_example: Your report contained several mistakes and it did not [give a] balanced view.

senses.definition: a healthy mixture of different types of food
dictionary_examples: If you have a balanced diet, you are getting all the vitamins you need.
senses.learner_example: It is very important to have a balanced diet.

senses.definition: to leave someone or something somewhere, sometimes not returning to get them
dictionary_examples: They were forced to abandon the car.
My sister abandoned me at the station, so I went home alone.
We were sinking fast, and the captain gave the order to abandon ship.
senses.learner_example: All at once, they abandoned their sacks of stolen property and ran for their lives!

senses.definition: to stop doing something before it is finished, or to stop following a plan, idea, etc.
dictionary_examples: The weather was so bad, we abandoned our plans for a picnic.
senses.learner_example: How would you feel if you establish[ed] a long-time plan for your career and then you ha[d] to abandon it?

senses.definition: left empty or not working
dictionary_examples: an abandoned house/building/mine
senses.learner_example: Arriving [at] an altitude of 2000m, people can visit the abandoned salt-mines.

senses.definition: having been left somewhere, intentionally
dictionary_examples: An abandoned baby was left at the hospital.
senses.learner_example: Please, just have a look [at] your wife Margaret and her eyes will tell you that she is this abandoned princess of your childhood fairy-tale.

senses.definition: the physical or mental skill or qualities that you need to do something
dictionary_examples: She had the ability to explain things clearly.
athletic/academic ability
senses.learner_example: The protagonist had been bitten by a strange spider and some days later, he noticed [he had] some strange powers, such as the ability to create spider[s'] webs.

senses.definition: a small amount or piece of something
dictionary_examples: There were little bits of paper all over the floor.
Be sure to sweep up every bit of the broken glass.
She tries to do a bit of exercise every day.
senses.learner_example: I'm not going because I'm feeling bad and I also have a bit of fever.

senses.definition: slightly
dictionary_examples: The dress is a bit too big for me.
That was a bit silly, wasn't it?
I'm a bit nervous.
Could I have a little bit more soup?
senses.learner_example: I'd like to walk or do any other sport, because I am a bit fat.

senses.definition: a short period of time
dictionary_examples: I'm just going out for a bit. See you later.
senses.learner_example: I had my breakfast, I went to buy the newspaper and then I came back to my house to rest [for] a bit.

senses.definition: a lot
dictionary_examples: He does quite a bit of traveling.
She's quite a bit older than him.
senses.learner_example: We spent quite a bit of time [going] along the beach.

senses.definition: small things or jobs which are not connected or not very important
dictionary_examples: We've packed most of it up now, there are just a few bits and pieces left.
senses.learner_example: So, it's memories that make us keep odd bits and pieces.

senses.definition: gradually
dictionary_examples: She saved up the money, bit by bit.
senses.learner_example: This film is full of tension as the truth is only revealed bit by bit.

senses.term: a bit of a surprise/problem/mess, etc.
senses.definition: a surprise, problem, mess, etc. that is not too big or serious
dictionary_examples: I am a bit of a romantic.
It was a bit of a shock.
senses.learner_example: It is sometimes a bit of a nu[i]sance to check every time whether both doors are well locked up.

senses.definition: a piece taken from food when you bite it
dictionary_examples: She took a bite of her pizza.
senses.learner_example: When Alice [took] a bite out of the cake, something hard touched her teeth.

senses.definition: an injury caused when an animal or insect bites you
dictionary_examples: mosquito bites
senses.learner_example: As far as your question about our sleeping is concerned, I wouldn't mind either staying in rooms or tents, but since you ask me to express my preference, I would suggest staying in rooms, in order to avoid insect bites.

senses.definition: a small meal
dictionary_examples: I just want to grab a bite to eat.
I had a bite at Laura's house.
senses.learner_example: It all went smoothly until 2 o'clock when they stopped for a break and a bite to eat.

senses.definition: to cut something using your teeth
dictionary_examples: He bit into the apple.
I was bitten by a dog.
senses.learner_example: A snake bit me [o]n my leg, but that's ok.

senses.definition: smart or good at doing something
dictionary_examples: She's a very able student.
senses.learner_example: They contend that this will lead to better grades, better results in key stage test[s], and a more able work force.

senses.definition: to have the ability to do something or the possibility of doing something
dictionary_examples: He'll be able to help you.
Will she be able to do the work?
I'm sorry that I wasn't able to call you yesterday.
It's so wonderful being able to see the ocean from my window.
senses.learner_example: I will be able to go to your house next Friday.

senses.definition: different from what is normal or usual, in a way which is strange or dangerous
dictionary_examples: abnormal behavior/conditions
We had an abnormal amount of snow.
senses.learner_example: You are all obliged to inform other worker[s] about the danger if you should notice anything that is abnormal.

senses.definition: on or onto a plane, ship, bus, or train
dictionary_examples: Once everyone was aboard the plane, the doors were closed and the crew prepared for takeoff.
senses.learner_example: While the food aboard your aircraft was regarded as excellent in 2004, its quality has dropped significantly this year.

senses.definition: to officially end something, especially a law or system
dictionary_examples: I think bullfighting should be abolished.
National Service was abolished in Britain in 1962.
senses.learner_example: Therefore, I suggest you should not change or abolish any event for any reason.

senses.definition: one of the hard pieces that make the structure inside a human or animal
dictionary_examples: The X-ray showed a broken bone in his left hand.
There's still a lot of meat left on the bone - should I slice some off for you?
senses.learner_example: I saw things like dinosaur bones, mummies, etc.

senses.definition: something that people argue about
dictionary_examples: Housework is a major bone of contention in our house.
senses.learner_example: Prices have always been the bone of contention among the managers.

senses.definition: If two people are lovers, they have a romantic or physical relationship.
dictionary_examples: They were friends before they became lovers.
senses.learner_example: I was reading "Romeo and Juliet" by W. Shakespeare when I suddenly decided to leave and visit Verona, the lovers' city.

senses.definition: someone who is very interested in books, cats, dogs, etc.
dictionary_examples: an opera lover
senses.learner_example: Brazil is a very big country and perfect for nature lovers.

senses.definition: a set of attached pages in a cover, with words or pictures that tell a story or provide information
dictionary_examples: I've read all his books.
She wrote a book about the island's history.
I bought a book about Quebec.
an art/picture/children's/reference book
senses.learner_example: I like reading books in the library.

senses.definition: a set of attached pages in a cover, which are blank to write or draw on or have spaces to record information
dictionary_examples: I need to get a composition/exercise book for writing class.
an order/address book
sketch-/notebooks
senses.learner_example: You have to bring with you some pencils for drawing and a drawing book.

senses.term: book sb in or book sb into sth
senses.definition: to arrange for someone to stay at a hotel
dictionary_examples: She booked me into a hotel uptown.
senses.learner_example: You all have been booked into the "Palace Hotel" which is one of the most comfortable [hotels] in town.

senses.definition: a set of stamps, tickets, etc. that are sold together inside a cover
dictionary_examples: I'll get a book of stamps when I go to the post office tomorrow.

senses.term: not judge a book by its cover
senses.definition: to not decide what someone or something is like only by looking at them
dictionary_examples: You know, his desk is a mess but don't judge a book by it's cover, he does careful, detailed work.
senses.learner_example: I'm simply pointing out one should never judge a book by it's cover as things aren't alway[s] what they seem.

senses.definition: to do something exactly according to the rules
dictionary_examples: The lawyers want to make sure we've done everything strictly by the book.
senses.learner_example: The upper-class people always do things by the book, follow the rules and the conventions and therefore are stand-offish and cold.

senses.definition: to arrange to use or do something at a particular time in the future
dictionary_examples: You need to book your flight before the fares go up.
Book early/in advance to get a good room.
The hotel is booked solid / fully booked for the next three weeks.
senses.learner_example: They told me that it's better to book a room in advance.

senses.definition: a medical method to end a pregnancy
dictionary_examples: to have an abortion
senses.learner_example: Some of these problems are serious and should be eliminated, such as abortion and domestic violence.

senses.definition: a little more or less than the stated number or amount
dictionary_examples: It happened about two months ago.
"What time are you leaving work today?" "About five."
senses.learner_example: It's not far [from] my home, about 20 minut[es'] walk, [or] 5 minut[es] by bus.

senses.definition: relating to a particular subject or person
dictionary_examples: What's she talking about?
I've got a book about Jung.
senses.learner_example: I like my IT course becaus[e] I want to learn about computers.

senses.definition: used when suggesting or offering something to someone
dictionary_examples: How about a trip to the zoo this afternoon?
"Coffee, Sarah?" "No, thanks." "What about you, Kate?"
How about cycling there?
senses.learner_example: What about going on Saturday?

senses.definition: used to ask for someone's opinion on a particular subject
dictionary_examples: What about Ava - is she nice?
So the town was nice - how about the food?
senses.learner_example: I also enjoy shopping for shoes, what about you?

senses.definition: to be going to do something very soon
dictionary_examples: I was about to leave when Mark arrived.
senses.learner_example: I'm in a hurry, my class is about to begin.

senses.definition: Time is what we measure in minutes, hours, days, etc.
dictionary_examples: He wants to spend more time with his family.
If you'd done your work instead of wasting time talking, you'd be finished by now.
She grew more and more fascinated by the subject as time went on/by.
senses.learner_example: I love [this game] and the last two days I [have] spen[t] all my time on it.

senses.definition: a particular point in the day or night
dictionary_examples: "What's the time?" "It's ten o'clock."
What time is it?
What time do you finish work?
Would you like to suggest a time for the meeting?
senses.learner_example: Do you know the times of the trains to London?

senses.definition: a particular amount of time
dictionary_examples: It takes a long time to get from Los Angeles to Sydney.
It was some time ago that I last heard from her.
We'd save time on our trip if we went by train.
What do you like doing in your spare/free time?
senses.learner_example: I don't know how you find time to do all the things you do.

senses.definition: a particular point of the day, week, month, year, etc. that is suitable for a particular activity, or at which something is expected to happen
dictionary_examples: vacation time
party time
When would be a good time for me to call you?
senses.learner_example: My father called me on the phone and told me it was time to go home!

senses.definition: an occasion or period, or the experience connected with it
dictionary_examples: The last time we went to Florida, it rained every day.
We were very young at the time.
Every time/Each time I ask you to do something, you always say you're too busy.
They go swimming three or four times a week.
senses.learner_example: Did you have a good time at the conference?

senses.definition: a period in history
dictionary_examples: Charles Dickens' novel "A Tale of Two Cities" is set at the time of the French Revolution.
In/During medieval times, women thought to be witches were burned at the stake.
In times gone by, all crops were harvested by hand.
He is widely regarded as one of the best writers of modern/our times.
senses.learner_example: We sat and talked about old times.

senses.definition: a number of minutes, hours, days, etc. that is available for something or that is needed for something
dictionary_examples: If I have time, I'll call Sam.
Have you got time for a quick drink after work?
I'd like to learn to sail, but I haven't the time.
I haven't got time to go shopping today.
senses.learner_example: She ran out of time and didn't finish the last question.

senses.definition: the time in a particular place
dictionary_examples: The plane arrives at 2:50, New York time.
senses.learner_example: By the way, I will be arriving on September 19, 2003, at around 8:00 p.m local time, I will be waiting for you at the arrival area of Newark International airport.

senses.definition: continuously
dictionary_examples: I wish you'd stop criticizing me all the time.
senses.learner_example: He laugh[s] all the time.

senses.definition: used to say that something should happen or be done now
dictionary_examples: It's time we got going.
OK kids, it's time for bed now.
It's time to leave for work.
senses.learner_example: My father called me on the phone and told me it was time to go home!

senses.definition: early or at the right time
dictionary_examples: We arrived in time to catch the train.
senses.learner_example: If I [don']t come back in time, you can put [a] note on my desk.

senses.definition: If two things happen at the same time, they happen together.
dictionary_examples: We arrived at the same time.
senses.learner_example: The kind of clothes I most like [are] casual but fashionable at the same time.

senses.definition: not early or late
dictionary_examples: I got to school on time.
senses.learner_example: So, I will not be on time for my English class tomorrow.

senses.definition: used to say how much bigger, better, worse, etc. one thing is than another thing
dictionary_examples: Ben earns three times more than me.
He gets paid nearly three times as much as me.
senses.learner_example: [I]n my opinion, you must visit the cities, [which are] three times better than the countryside.

senses.term: in a day's/two months', etc. time
senses.definition: a week, two months, etc. from now
dictionary_examples: I have to go to the doctor again in a month's time.
senses.learner_example: We are back in 2 weeks' time.

senses.definition: used at the beginning of a story to mean a long time ago
dictionary_examples: Once upon a time there was a beautiful princess.
senses.learner_example: Once upon a time there was a very poor family.

senses.definition: sometimes but not often
dictionary_examples: From time to time I still think of her.
senses.learner_example: I wash the dishes from time to time (I sometimes try to avoid this unpleasant duty) and clean our house.

senses.definition: for a long period of time
dictionary_examples: I've been doing yoga for some time.
senses.learner_example: I have been observing you for some time and it's now quite clear to me that you have been working too hard since you changed your job.

senses.definition: If it is about time or high time that someone did something, it should have been done sooner or a long time ago.
dictionary_examples: It's about time the school improved its cafeteria service.
It’s high time you got that bad knee looked at by a doctor!
senses.learner_example: If not, it i[s]about time you found out everything about this device you use every day!

senses.definition: to leave enough time to do something although you are busy
dictionary_examples: You have to make time to do your homework.
He never made enough time for family life.
senses.learner_example: I'm terribly sorry for not being able to make time to pick you up when you arrive.

senses.definition: sometimes
dictionary_examples: At times, I wish I didn't have to go to school.
senses.learner_example: STUDYING METHODS All teachers at the college are high[ly] skilled professionals and can be very demanding at times, but this is [in] your best interest.

senses.definition: to do something without hurrying
dictionary_examples: Take your time choosing - there's no hurry.
senses.learner_example: If you're going to land at the "Lugano-Agno" airport, as you told me in your last letter, the first thing I recommend to you is to be patient and take your time.

senses.definition: again and again on repeated occasions
dictionary_examples: We’ve been hearing the same news story time after time.
senses.learner_example: Time after time he stopped and looked around, not sure if [he] was alone.

senses.term: it's only a matter of time
senses.definition: If you say that it is only a matter of time before something happens, you are sure it will happen but you do not know when.
dictionary_examples: It's only a matter of time before someone gets into an accident on this road.
senses.learner_example: In my opinion it is only a matter of time before it is decided to [put] an end to this country being a kingdom.

senses.definition: to have no respect for someone or something
dictionary_examples: I have no time for people who wont even listen to another point of view.
senses.learner_example: First of all it's hard work, I have no time for la[z]y people.

senses.definition: to criticize someone and make them feel guilty about something they have done
dictionary_examples: Ever since I missed that catch, the other players have been giving me a hard time.
senses.learner_example: I'm not saying that I wasn't normal or anything, I just gave my family a hard time sometimes.

senses.definition: not fashionable or modern
dictionary_examples: Dad's a bit behind the times.
senses.learner_example: We [should] improve our equipment. Otherwise we will be behind the times.

senses.definition: used to talk about an occasion in the past without saying exactly which occasion it was
dictionary_examples: Most of us have made a similar mistake at one time or another.
senses.learner_example: Haven't we all at one time or another come home from a holiday feeling healthy and strong with a smile on our face thinking, this is what life is about.

senses.definition: used to show that something is not good when it is the best it can be
dictionary_examples: He's not exactly patient at the best of times.
senses.learner_example: They knew that even at the best of times he looked unpleasant but now he was of [a] completely different [appearance].

senses.definition: very soon
dictionary_examples: We'll be home in no time.
senses.learner_example: Team work is very important for us and you will make many friends in no time.

senses.definition: to measure how long it takes for something to happen or for someone to do something
dictionary_examples: It's a good idea to time yourself while you do the exercises.

senses.definition: to arrange for something to happen at a particular time
dictionary_examples: We timed our arrivals at the airport so that we could meet and share a taxi to the city.

senses.definition: in or to a higher position than something else
dictionary_examples: There's a mirror above the sink.
Her name comes above mine on the list.
senses.learner_example: I think I have [put] it above the bookshelf.

senses.definition: more than an amount or level
dictionary_examples: It says on the box it's for children age three and above.
Rates of pay are above average.
senses.learner_example: The weather is too hot in Beijing. Every day [it] is above 30 degrees.

senses.definition: too good or important for something
dictionary_examples: No one is above suspicion in this matter.

senses.definition: higher on the page
dictionary_examples: the above diagram
Match these words with the pictures above.
Please send the articles to the address given/shown above.
senses.learner_example: I can be contacted at the above address and I would be free to attend an interview at any time from Monday to Saturday.

senses.definition: most importantly
dictionary_examples: Above all, I'd like to thank my family.
He is known above all for his movies.
senses.learner_example: She is a very nice person and above all, she is really cheerful.

senses.definition: completely or very
dictionary_examples: The cake was all eaten last night.
You're all wet!
Tell me all about your trip.
senses.learner_example: I'm going to tell you all about it.

senses.definition: the whole of a period of time
dictionary_examples: I've been studying all day.
It rained all week.
I've been waiting all afternoon for him to call.
senses.learner_example: I spent all day [at the] beach.

senses.definition: every person or thing in a group
dictionary_examples: I've seen all of his movies.
All of us had left by midnight.
She's got four children, all under the age of five.
"Which of his books did you like best?" "I loved them all."
senses.learner_example: I hope you are all well.

senses.definition: the whole amount of something
dictionary_examples: I've spent all my money.
Did you drink all the juice?
By morning, all the snow had gone.
senses.learner_example: I have left my purse at your home. I have all my money in it.

senses.definition: the only thing
dictionary_examples: All I remember is waking up in the hospital.
All you can do is hope he'll get better.
senses.learner_example: Actually, I lost my job last week. All I can do is buy a computer and get [on] the internet to find [another] job.

senses.definition: many different types of something
dictionary_examples: They had all sorts of jewelry for sale.
We saw all sorts of animals in the park.
senses.learner_example: I like all sorts of music but I prefer urban music!

senses.definition: used to say that you hope someone will be happy, healthy, successful, etc., often when saying goodbye
dictionary_examples: Well, all the best - it was nice meeting you.
Please wish him all the best in his new job.
senses.learner_example: I want to wish you all the best!

senses.definition: continuously
dictionary_examples: I wish you'd stop criticizing me all the time.
senses.learner_example: He laugh[s] all the time.

senses.definition: used for emphasis in questions or negative statements, to mean in any way or of any type
dictionary_examples: Can I help at all?
He hasn't changed at all.
senses.learner_example: The sun was shining and there were no clouds at all, so we could see the light blue sky.

senses.definition: most importantly
dictionary_examples: Above all, I'd like to thank my family.
He is known above all for his movies.
senses.learner_example: She is a very nice person and above all, she is really cheerful.

senses.definition: everything is in a good or acceptable state
dictionary_examples: I hope all is well with Jack.
senses.learner_example: I hope all's well.

senses.definition: used to add information that shows that what you have just said is true
dictionary_examples: You can't expect to be perfect - after all, it was only your first lesson.
senses.learner_example: I stopped talking with my friends, but not [for long] - after all, we are friends. Anyway, I'm planning nice things for the next April 1st.

senses.definition: used to show the total amount of something
dictionary_examples: Some of the children came, so there were 15 of us in all.
senses.learner_example: Secondly, even though most people like[d] [the] group RADIANT, they [only] played for 35 minutes in all.

senses.definition: repeated from the beginning
dictionary_examples: We had to start all over again.
senses.learner_example: After that I went back to my home in Ribeirao Preto to begin my routine all over again.

senses.definition: suddenly
dictionary_examples: All of a sudden, he came running in.
senses.learner_example: All of a sudden, a weird creature popped into his dream.

senses.definition: used for saying that other similar things are included or that the whole of a situation is considered
dictionary_examples: He told us about his school and all.
We decided to stay in bed, with it being a holiday and all that.
senses.learner_example: I really enjoy shopping for clothes, but not only for clothes, also for things like earrings and all that!

senses.definition: used to say that something happened or was true although you did not expect it to happen or be true
dictionary_examples: Helen couldn't come to the party after all.
senses.learner_example: Cars still enter the city so there will be pollution after all.

senses.definition: suddenly
dictionary_examples: All at once he stood up and walked out of the room.
senses.learner_example: All at once, everything started to work again.

senses.definition: very late at night, until early morning, or almost all the time
dictionary_examples: Our neighbors play loud music at all hours of the day and night.
senses.learner_example: This causes traffic jams at all hours of the day.

senses.definition: used for saying that something is true in general if you think about all its aspects
dictionary_examples: The show was a great success, all things considered.
senses.learner_example: All things considered, it seems like "Kavanagh Catering Services" would be most suitable for the students.

senses.definition: despite
dictionary_examples: For all her qualifications, she's useless at the job.
senses.learner_example: For all of his desire to be strong, Okonkwo is haunted [by] fear.

senses.definition: in every place
dictionary_examples: He's traveled all over the world.
senses.learner_example: The people in the class are from all over the world.

senses.definition: from the beginning of a period of time
dictionary_examples: I knew all along that it was a mistake.
senses.learner_example: In the future the key word for fashion will be comfort as this is basically what everyone has been wanting all along.

senses.definition: considering everything
dictionary_examples: All in all, it was a great vacation.
senses.learner_example: All in all, nobody cares about air pollution and the environment in general.

senses.definition: in or to many different places
dictionary_examples: There were dirty dishes all over the place.
senses.learner_example: There w[as] plenty of food and drinks, and there were about 180 guests dancing and chat[t]ing all over the place.

senses.definition: used to show that you do not agree with something or that you are annoyed about something
dictionary_examples: It's all very well for her to say everything's fine, she doesn't have to live here.
senses.learner_example: That's all very well for most of the people but according to my desires [i]t's not enough.

senses.definition: much better, easier, more exciting, etc.
dictionary_examples: The journey was all the more dangerous because of the bad weather.
senses.learner_example: He had to overcome great obstacles in his professional and private lives, which makes his achievements all the more remarkable.

senses.definition: to be ready
dictionary_examples: We were all set to go when the phone rang.
senses.learner_example: So, there you go. I'm all set!

senses.definition: almost
dictionary_examples: The movie was all but over by the time we got there.
senses.learner_example: He could all but hear their stomachs rumble.

senses.definition: travel in an aircraft
dictionary_examples: I don't travel much by air.
air travel
senses.learner_example: I [will] travel there by air.

senses.definition: the mixture of gases that surrounds the earth and that we breathe
dictionary_examples: I went outside to get some fresh air.
senses.learner_example: There are lots of different kinds of animals, lakes, fresh air and trees.

senses.definition: a particular appearance or quality
dictionary_examples: He has an air of confidence.
senses.learner_example: The service is excellent and the atmosphere is quite nice, with an air of elegance.

senses.definition: the space above and around things
dictionary_examples: He kicked the ball high in the air.
senses.learner_example: It was an old painting. In it, a man was holding his axe up in the air and was ready to hit a tree.

senses.definition: played on television or radio
dictionary_examples: His show is on the air from 11:00 to 11:30 Monday through Thursday.
senses.learner_example: As you can see, it’s probably the first chance to learn good English on T.V. Another surprising thing is that it's not on the air too late, so you can watch it without oversleeping in the morning.

senses.definition: to get rid of bad feelings between two people or groups
dictionary_examples: We had a big argument, but I think it helped clear the air.
The meeting Friday will help clear the air and clarify some issues that need to be addressed.
senses.learner_example: I rushed into the room [to] cheer them up and clear the air, although I knew it was too late.

senses.definition: to suddenly disappear in a mysterious way
dictionary_examples: He was on the path ahead of me and then vanished into thin air.
senses.learner_example: Sitting on a couch and squeezed between my elderly aunts, I sincerely wished I could vanish into thin air.

senses.definition: someone or something that is new, different, and exciting
dictionary_examples: Having Eve around has been a breath of fresh air.
senses.learner_example: Should this be everything the Town Council has promised, it will bring a breath of fresh air for our local youth.

senses.definition: the air that goes into and out of your lungs
dictionary_examples: Her breath smelled of garlic.
senses.learner_example: Then I felt someone's breath on my shoulder...

senses.definition: to be breathing quickly because you have been running, walking fast, etc.
dictionary_examples: He burst into the room, red-faced and out of breath.
senses.learner_example: Although I was out of breath I started to run faster and faster.

senses.definition: to keep air in your lungs and not let it out
dictionary_examples: How long can you hold your breath under water?
senses.learner_example: My heart was beating fast. I was holding my breath.

senses.definition: If something takes your breath away, you feel surprise and admiration because it is so beautiful or exciting.
dictionary_examples: The view from the window took my breath away.
senses.learner_example: The landscape just takes your breath away sometimes.

senses.definition: to fill your lungs with air
dictionary_examples: Take a deep breath and relax.
senses.learner_example: But if you took a deep breath after reading the question, don't worry.

senses.definition: to rest for a short time until you can breathe regularly again
dictionary_examples: Let's stop here and catch our breath.
senses.learner_example: Unfortunately, the rooms we stayed in were on the 4th floor. The older people couldn't catch their breath when they finally arrived there!

senses.definition: If you say something under your breath, you say it very quietly so that other people cannot clearly hear it.
dictionary_examples: "It's time to go," she muttered under her breath.
senses.learner_example: "We must have taken a wrong turn somewhere..." he kept muttering under his breath.

senses.definition: in an excited or anxious way
dictionary_examples: I waited with bated breath as the results were read out.
senses.learner_example: Nevertheless, a huge number of scientists carrying out very useful research, [and] composers, actors, [and] artists making us watch their creations with bated breath, do not earn [as much] money as a lot of outstanding sportsmen do.

senses.definition: someone or something that is new, different, and exciting
dictionary_examples: Having Eve around has been a breath of fresh air.
senses.learner_example: Should this be everything the Town Council has promised, it will bring a breath of fresh air for our local youth.

senses.definition: to wait for something to happen, often feeling anxious
dictionary_examples: While the leaders negotiated, the world held its breath.
senses.learner_example: They, the critics, the fans and friends and his wife, held their breath and crossed their fingers, hoping to once again hear his enchanting voice.

senses.definition: new or different from what was there before
dictionary_examples: We're looking for fresh ideas.
We need to take a fresh look at the problem.
They decided to move abroad and make a fresh start.
senses.learner_example: In fact, it was the chance of a new life, the opportunity to make a fresh start.

senses.definition: Fresh food has been produced or collected recently and has not been frozen, dried, etc.
dictionary_examples: fresh fruit/vegetables/fish/bread
senses.learner_example: Sometimes they go to the sea to get really fresh fish.

senses.definition: smelling clean or feeling pleasantly cool
dictionary_examples: a fresh smell/breeze
senses.learner_example: The water was wonderfully fresh.

senses.definition: Fresh skin looks healthy.
dictionary_examples: a fresh complexion
senses.learner_example: Her eyes were blue and she had a beautiful fresh complexion.

senses.definition: having a lot of energy and not feeling tired
dictionary_examples: We got up the next day feeling fresh and relaxed.
senses.learner_example: Before the test, you should have your breakfast with a cup of coffee to make yourself feel fresh.

senses.definition: recently made, done, arrived, etc., and especially not yet changed by time
dictionary_examples: There was a fresh fall of snow during the night.
Some people like the smell of fresh paint, but I don't.
The events of last year are still fresh in people's minds.
senses.learner_example: I don't know if it is the most embar[r]assing moment of my life, but it is still fresh in my memory and I get embar[r]assed every time I think of it.

senses.definition: air outside buildings or away from the city that is clean and cool
dictionary_examples: Let's go outside and get some fresh air.
senses.learner_example: I think [it] would be better [to] go to the south east to the countryside and have a nice relaxing time with lots of fresh air.

senses.definition: water from lakes, rivers, etc. that has no salt in it
dictionary_examples: These fish live in fresh water.
senses.learner_example: You find stunning white beaches, clear, fresh water lakes, isolated tropic islands, reef, rainforests, buzzing cities, challenging mountain range, bush, outback - and the desert.

senses.definition: someone or something that is new, different, and exciting
dictionary_examples: Having Eve around has been a breath of fresh air.
senses.learner_example: Should this be everything the Town Council has promised, it will bring a breath of fresh air for our local youth.

senses.definition: in or to a foreign country
dictionary_examples: He's gone abroad on business.
We always go abroad in the summer.
senses.learner_example: I have never been abroad.

senses.definition: wide
dictionary_examples: We walked down a broad avenue lined with trees.
He has very broad shoulders.
a broad smile
senses.learner_example: Joss Merlyn was seven feet high, with broad, immense shoulders.

senses.definition: a group that includes many different things or people
dictionary_examples: The magazine covers a broad range of subjects, from sewing to psychology.
senses.learner_example: My last employer asked me to work again this summer. [H]owever, I would like to have a broad experience in different camps.

senses.definition: damaged and separated into pieces
dictionary_examples: He attacked the man with a broken bottle.
Careful - there's broken glass on the floor.
senses.learner_example: The first thing we saw was a broken window.

senses.definition: no longer able to work
dictionary_examples: My watch is broken.
senses.learner_example: My bicycle is broken.

senses.definition: an arm/leg, etc. with a damaged bone
dictionary_examples: Her little brother has a broken arm.
senses.learner_example: I stayed there for 2 weeks with a broken leg [and] sore ribs.

senses.definition: when you are very sad because of the end of a relationship
dictionary_examples: They said she died of a broken heart.
senses.learner_example: He will split up with you and [you] will get a broken heart!

senses.definition: a family in which the parents do not now live together
dictionary_examples: Many of these children come from broken homes.
senses.learner_example: The development of the modern society has brought with it a growing number of broken homes, divorces and economic problems which have directly affected the parent-child relationship.

senses.definition: English/Spanish, etc. that is spoken slowly and has a lot of mistakes in it
dictionary_examples: I managed to make myself understood in broken French.
senses.learner_example: A non-English speaker may be [able] to talk in broken English to a native English speaker, but has only [a vague] idea as to what he's uttering.

senses.definition: to the place where you live
dictionary_examples: He didn't come home until midnight.
I went home to visit my parents.
senses.learner_example: I must go home at midnight because I have to travel tomorrow.

senses.definition: at or in the place someone lives
dictionary_examples: Will you be home tomorrow evening?
senses.learner_example: I'll not be home this afternoon.

senses.definition: the place where you live or feel you belong
dictionary_examples: I tried to call him, but he wasn't at home.
We sold our home in Dallas and moved to Atlanta.
He left home when he was eighteen.
I was actually born in New Zealand, but I've lived in England for so long that it feels like home now.
senses.learner_example: That's why I love my home.

senses.definition: a place where a group of people who need special care live
dictionary_examples: a nursing home
My grandmother lives in a home now.
senses.learner_example: I've had a part time job as a nurs[ing] assistant at a home for elderly people, I've worked in a souvenir shop in Norway, and I've been away as an au pair in England.

senses.definition: to feel happy and confident in a place or situation
dictionary_examples: After a month she felt at home in her new job.
senses.learner_example: I explained: "I was in Manchester for just 10 month[s] and [during] that time the people from there made me feel at home [so] I feel proud to have the accent."

senses.definition: the place where you usually find something or someone, or where they come from
dictionary_examples: France, the home of good food
senses.learner_example: Every golfer - and those watching golf - know, that the home of golf is St. Andrews in Scotland.

senses.definition: to behave in a relaxed way in a place, as if it was your own home
dictionary_examples: Take off your coat and make yourself at home.
senses.learner_example: Please relax and make yourself at home and help yourself.

senses.definition: a family in which the parents do not now live together
dictionary_examples: Many of these children come from broken homes.
senses.learner_example: The development of the modern society has brought with it a growing number of broken homes, divorces and economic problems which have directly affected the parent-child relationship.

senses.definition: dealing with people in a quick, direct way that is unfriendly or rude
dictionary_examples: She can be rather abrupt.
senses.learner_example: I was poorly received and the general tone of the person assisting me was rude and abrupt.

senses.definition: sudden and not expected
dictionary_examples: Our conversation came to an abrupt end/halt.
senses.learner_example: Their income came from the revenues obtained by selling milk, fruit, jelly and other perishable goods, but they had to pay John, or their happy lifestyle would come to an abrupt end.

senses.definition: suddenly and quickly
dictionary_examples: They abruptly left the party.
His speech ended abruptly and he left the stage.
senses.learner_example: When she became an adolescent, her perspective changed abruptly.

senses.definition: when someone is not where they are usually expected to be
dictionary_examples: A new manager was appointed during/in her absence.
She has had repeated absences from school this year.
senses.learner_example: Anyway, during your absence, the T.V. repair man never appear[ed] and I had to insist by phone on your behalf.

senses.definition: when something does not exist
dictionary_examples: He drew attention to the absence of concrete evidence against the defendant.
senses.learner_example: The biggest difference the absence of TV made in my life was that I actually started living.

senses.definition: not in the place where you are expected to be, especially at school or work
dictionary_examples: John has been absent from school/work for three days now.
senses.learner_example: I'm going to be absent because my grandmother is ill and I have to take care of her.

senses.definition: complete and definite
dictionary_examples: absolute power/control
That's absolute nonsense!
Repairing the heating system is an absolute necessity!
senses.learner_example: I have no experience in surfing - I am an absolute beginner with high motivation.

senses.definition: completely
dictionary_examples: The food was absolutely delicious.
It's absolutely ridiculous.
I have absolutely no idea what she's talking about.
We've achieved absolutely nothing today.
senses.learner_example: I absolutely hate it.

senses.definition: used to strongly agree with someone
dictionary_examples: "Do you think it helped his career?" "Absolutely."
"It was an excellent movie, though." "Absolutely!"
senses.learner_example: So don't you think it was unfair and little rude to say that in your newspaper? Absolutely.

senses.definition: used to strongly disagree with someone or to agree with something negative
dictionary_examples: "Are you suggesting that we should just ignore the problem?" "No, absolutely not."
senses.learner_example: Does it mean the parents will allow them to eat anything they please? Absolutely not. You have to give the children some options, instead of imposing things on them.

senses.definition: to give all your attention to something that you are doing
dictionary_examples: Simon was so absorbed in his computer game that he didn't notice me come in.
senses.learner_example: We hadn't noticed them at first because we were absorbed in [listening to the] birds singing.

senses.definition: to take something in, especially gradually
dictionary_examples: Plants absorb carbon dioxide.
The drug is quickly absorbed into the bloodstream.
senses.learner_example: Everything is getting intermingled and absorbed into the system, making life terribly efficient, quick and easy.

senses.definition: to understand and remember facts that you read or hear
dictionary_examples: It's hard to absorb so much information.
senses.learner_example: You will have only three school [subjects] and that'[ll] make it easier to absorb the new knowledge.

senses.definition: relating to ideas and not real things
dictionary_examples: abstract ideas
Truth and beauty are abstract concepts.
senses.learner_example: Reading improve[s] your ability to imagine and your abstract thinking skills.

senses.definition: Abstract art involves shapes and colors and not images of real things or people.
dictionary_examples: abstract paintings/sculpture
senses.learner_example: What kind of material will you use for this painting? Will it be a realistic picture or an abstract one?

senses.definition: very silly
dictionary_examples: What an absurd explanation!
Don't be so absurd! Of course I want you to come.
It's an absurd situation - neither of them will talk to the other.
senses.learner_example: It is not a big city and I think it's absurd that people that live and work in it use the car to go to school or to work.

senses.definition: a number of things that are tied together
dictionary_examples: a bundle of letters/clothes
senses.learner_example: It was a bundle of papers hanging out of a hole in the ceiling.

senses.definition: a very energetic/nervous person
dictionary_examples: I was a bundle of nerves before the speech.
senses.learner_example: When he began to be a bundle of nerves, he understood that he had to ask her [for] the truth.

senses.definition: on fire
dictionary_examples: A man staggered from the burning car.
senses.learner_example: I saw a burning car.

senses.definition: a subject or question that must be taken care of or answered quickly
dictionary_examples: Climate change remains a burning issue.
senses.learner_example: Your staff is very nice but we are sorry to learn that they only speak English. It's a burning issue for us because we have few European travelers: German, Italian or French.

senses.definition: a very strong need to do something
dictionary_examples: I have no burning desire to go diving.
senses.learner_example: My most important quality is my burning desire to make a change.

senses.definition: bad or cruel treatment of people or animals
dictionary_examples: sexual/psychological/mental abuse
The rescued dogs had been victims of physical abuse.
senses.learner_example: The one side opposes this treatment as an abuse of living creatures while the other side denies any suffering and points at the values of zoos for people.

senses.definition: the use of a substance in an unsuitable and harmful way or for the wrong purpose
dictionary_examples: Drug and alcohol abuse contributed to his early death.
This program tries to address problems that lead to substance abuse.
senses.learner_example: Get information about the [effect]s of drug abuse and make your generation a better one.

senses.definition: an action or activity that is morally wrong or not allowed
dictionary_examples: The mayor was suspected of corruption and other abuses.
The committee is investigating the abuse of tax-exempt status by charities.
senses.learner_example: It is a vast resource of information, but the abuse of it may have detrimental consequences.

senses.definition: rude and offensive words said to another person
dictionary_examples: He found it difficult to tolerate the verbal abuse.
senses.learner_example: I went all the way back cycling on the wrong side of the road, and anyone who said something about it could expect a stream of abuse.

senses.definition: saying rude and offensive words to someone
dictionary_examples: an abusive phone call
senses.learner_example: This is partly true, because even [a] slightly abusive expression might result in discord or [rupture] between seemingly close friends.

senses.definition: relating to schools, colleges, and universities, or to subjects that involve thinking and studying and not technical or practical skills
dictionary_examples: academic subjects/programs/institutions
academic standards/achievement
senses.learner_example: As a member of our academic community, I'm very glad to hear that our college will have a surplus in its annual budget.

senses.definition: when you use the telephone
dictionary_examples: Could you give me a call when you have time?
I got a call from Pete last night.
There was a call for you earlier.
I've just got a couple of calls to make.
senses.learner_example: I'll take the call in my office.

senses.definition: when someone shouts something
dictionary_examples: She could hear calls for help from inside the burning building.
I'll be in the next room, so give me a call if you need any help.
senses.learner_example: I continued on towards Kingsley Road where the call for help had been made.

senses.definition: a short visit
dictionary_examples: I thought I'd pay Gary a call.
senses.learner_example: During our stay in Dublin we [took] a half-day trip by bus throughout the city, which was an unforgettable experience, and paid a call to the National Museum as well.

senses.definition: to telephone someone again, or to telephone someone who telephoned you earlier
dictionary_examples: I'm kind of busy - can I call you back later?
senses.learner_example: If you get this note, call me back if you have a problem [on] 5681275.

senses.definition: to go to a place in order to meet and travel with someone
dictionary_examples: I'll call for you at eight.
senses.learner_example: I'll call for you on Friday afternoon.

senses.definition: to demand that something happens
dictionary_examples: to call for a ban on guns
senses.learner_example: You, as the local newspaper, [are] in the proper position to call for a collective reaction against the supermarket proposal.

senses.term: call off sth or call sth off
senses.definition: to decide that a planned event or activity will not happen because it is not possible, useful or wanted now
dictionary_examples: Tomorrow's match has been called off because of the icy weather.
senses.learner_example: Take me, for example, I use it whenever there is a problem and I need some advice, or when I have to call off a meeting for any reason.

senses.term: call off sth or call sth off
senses.definition: to decide to stop an activity
dictionary_examples: Police have called off the search.
senses.learner_example: However, it has not been such a bad situation, and since the strike was called off two days ago everything is getting back to normal.

senses.term: call on sb to do sth
senses.definition: to ask someone in a formal way to do something
dictionary_examples: He called on the rebels to stop fighting.
senses.learner_example: I saw an advertisement [i]n the local newspaper, The Leader, calling on residents in this area to help carry out a project to clean up the local environment.

senses.definition: to telephone someone
dictionary_examples: Why don't you call me up at home?
senses.learner_example: After a few minutes, I went to a phone booth and called up my friend to apologi[z]e.

senses.definition: to be ordered to join a military organization or asked to join a sports team
dictionary_examples: He was called up soon after the war started.
The team has called up several players from the minor leagues.
senses.learner_example: The very next day her husband was called up to join the army.

senses.term: call up sth or call sth up
senses.definition: to find and show information on a computer screen
dictionary_examples: Can you call up last year's sales figures on Janice's computer?
senses.learner_example: The internet is also a great source of information and you can find almost anything you could be possibly interested in [there], starting with various kinds of music that you can freely download from the internet, [and] books you can call up on your screen straight from the online library or dictionaries, including the famous Cambridge Dictionary of English.

senses.definition: to have a particular name
dictionary_examples: a boy called Adam
Their latest album is called "In Rainbows."
senses.learner_example: My friend is called Jessica.

senses.definition: to telephone the place where you work and report that you are sick and unable to work
dictionary_examples: Three people called in sick this morning.
senses.learner_example: A few minutes after the concert began, a backstage assistant called in sick who was responsible for checking w[h]ether everything is going well according to the timetable.

senses.definition: to stop doing something, especially working
dictionary_examples: It's almost midnight - let's call it a day.
senses.learner_example: From the begin[n]ing of the day [I] and my family were doing household chores. When, in the afterno[o]n we stop[p]ed and called it a day, the doorbell rang.

senses.definition: to arrange for a meeting to happen
dictionary_examples: The chairman has called an emergency meeting.
senses.learner_example: We hope you w[ill] call a meeting to discuss this matter in detail.

senses.definition: to use impolite or unpleasant words to describe someone
dictionary_examples: He said the other children were calling him names.
senses.learner_example: He had never called me names or told me off.

senses.definition: a demand for something to happen
dictionary_examples: a call for action/peace
senses.learner_example: Their demands included an all-out call for vital reforms in education - not, as one might expect, a call for higher salaries.

senses.definition: when someone can decide something
dictionary_examples: I don't care what we do - it's your call.
senses.learner_example: This is my opinon, but it is your call, talk to your parents.

senses.definition: to telephone someone
dictionary_examples: She called me this morning at the office.
Your mom called last night when you were out.
I've been calling all morning but I can't get hold of him.
I called the police.
senses.learner_example: For more information, call this number 0862 410919.

senses.definition: to give someone or something a particular name
dictionary_examples: They've called the twins Katherine and Thomas.
His real name is Jonathan, but they've always called him "Johnny."
senses.learner_example: Two months later, the baby girl was born and [she] called her "Mary."

senses.definition: to say something in a loud voice, especially in order to attract someone's attention
dictionary_examples: Did you call?
I thought I heard someone call my name.
Someone in the crowd called (out) his name.
"Hey, come over here!" she called.
senses.learner_example: I ignored the voice, but again someone called me.

senses.definition: to describe someone or something in a particular way
dictionary_examples: Are you calling me a liar?
He called it a disgrace.
senses.learner_example: You work too hard and you could be called [a] work[a]holic.

senses.definition: to ask someone to come somewhere
dictionary_examples: She called me into her office.
He called me over to where he was sitting.
I keep the bedroom door open in case the children call for me during the night.
senses.learner_example: I was called to an emergency meeting this morning.

senses.definition: to start to happen more quickly, or to make something start to happen more quickly
dictionary_examples: Inflation is likely to accelerate this year.
senses.learner_example: Fashion has always been changing but I think this process accelerated after the Second World War.

senses.definition: to move or cause yourself or a vehicle to move faster
dictionary_examples: The car in front accelerated and left us behind.
senses.learner_example: When I ride my bike and start accelerating, I feel that I move with the speed of the wind.

senses.definition: the way in which people in a particular area, country or social group pronounce words
dictionary_examples: a Boston/Southern accent
He speaks with a heavy/strong Russian accent.
senses.learner_example: Our teacher is a middle-aged lady with a kind smile and [a] British accent.

senses.definition: a mark written or printed over a letter to show you how to pronounce it
dictionary_examples: There's an acute accent on the "e" of "café."

senses.definition: to admit that you caused something bad that happened
dictionary_examples: I accept full responsibility for the failure of the plan.

senses.definition: to agree to take something that is offered to you
dictionary_examples: to accept an apology/invitation/offer
I've been invited to their wedding, but I haven't decided whether to accept.
She won't accept advice from anyone.
senses.learner_example: I hope that you accept my apology.

senses.definition: to admit that something is true, often something unpleasant
dictionary_examples: He refuses to accept that he's made a mistake.
I can't accept that there's nothing we can do.
senses.learner_example: David told her that the reason [for] his failure was her, because she used to press him a lot and she couldn't accept that he wanted to be an actor.

senses.definition: to allow someone to join an organization or become part of a group
dictionary_examples: She was accepted to two of the universities she applied to.
He was accepted as a full member of the society.
His fellow workers refused to accept him.
senses.learner_example: When I returned home I check[ed] my mail and I ha[d] a new message from my uncle, saying that the university have accepted me.

senses.definition: good enough
dictionary_examples: This kind of behavior is not acceptable.
We need an arrangement that is acceptable to both parties.
So what is an acceptable level of radiation?
senses.learner_example: I am sure that finally I will succeed in [us]ing English in an acceptable way!

senses.definition: allowed or approved of
dictionary_examples: It's not socially acceptable to wear jeans and a T-shirt to a wedding.
senses.learner_example: They should teach them what is right [and] wrong, and what is morally and socially acceptable.

senses.definition: when you accept something
dictionary_examples: His acceptance of the award was controversial.
There is a growing public acceptance of alternative medicine.
senses.learner_example: The main reason for the "fast-food" groceries winning acceptance in Swedish culture is lack of time.

senses.definition: agreed with or approved of by most people
dictionary_examples: an accepted spelling
senses.learner_example: Competition can also be an accepted form of expression of one's aggression.

senses.definition: the right or opportunity to use or look at something
dictionary_examples: Internet access
The system has been designed to give the user quick and easy access to the required information.
senses.learner_example: I would suggest free Internet access as an extra facility in our library.

senses.definition: the way in which you can enter a place or get to a place
dictionary_examples: disabled access
The only access to the island is by boat.
senses.learner_example: [I]t will be tempting for the companies in town to move out where there is more space for expansion and easier access by trucks and cars.

senses.definition: to find or see information, especially using a computer
dictionary_examples: You can access the files over the Internet.
senses.learner_example: We have more time to stay together at home, because we can access [the] internet at home.

senses.definition: able to be reached or easily gotten
dictionary_examples: The island resort is accessible by plane or ferry.
senses.learner_example: The museum is near the city center and is accessible by bus or walking.

senses.definition: easy to understand
dictionary_examples: They are attempting to make opera accessible to a wider audience.
senses.learner_example: Jacques Prevert, the French poet, changed our way [of seeing] the world by making poetry accessible to everyone.
